issue: No headline or title at the top
description: Your name is not your identity. Recruiters want to know what role you’re targeting within seconds. Without a clear title like 'Data Analyst' or 'Business Intelligence Specialist', you’re just another generic profile.
fix: Add a headline below your name.
example: Data Analyst | Power BI | SQL | Business Insights

description: Most summaries are just a dump of tools, e.g., 'Experienced with Excel, Python, Tableau…' But that doesn’t tell a story.
fix: Talk outcomes, not just tools. Emphasize what you achieved using those tools.
example: Built dashboards that reduced inventory errors by 15% and improved warehouse efficiency by 20%.

description: Skills like 'Teamwork' and 'Problem-solving' are overused and don’t help distinguish you. Recruiters need ATS-friendly keywords that match the job description.
fix: Use specific, technical skills and keywords relevant to the job.
example: SQL | Power BI | Data Cleaning | A/B Testing | Python | Data Visualization

description: Simply stating 'reduced cost by 10%' is good, but it lacks context on how it was achieved.
fix: Use an Action + Tool + Result format to show your method.
example: Automated reporting with Python, saving 10+ hours/week and reducing manual errors by 30%.

description: For a data analyst, not including a portfolio or GitHub link is a missed opportunity to provide evidence of your work.
fix: Add a portfolio or GitHub link at the top or bottom of your resume, highlighting 2–3 key projects.
example: Include: 'Portfolio: github.com/yourusername' or a link to your online portfolio.

description: Generic objectives like 'Seeking a challenging role…' are fluff. They don’t show your intent or how you align with the role.
fix: Write a concise one-liner that clearly shows your intent and role alignment.
example: Looking to leverage 3+ years of analytics experience to drive decision-making in a fast-paced product company.
